passage:
(1) In recent years, the relationship between big companies and small businesses has become increasingly complex. While large corporations bring economic growth and job opportunities to communities, they also present significant challenges to local entrepreneurs. Small businesses, which are often family-owned and operated, must adapt quickly to survive in markets dominated by these powerful competitors.

(2) One of the most immediate impacts of big companies entering local markets is the price competition they introduce. Large corporations can negotiate better deals with suppliers due to their purchasing power, allowing them to offer lower prices than small businesses. This advantage often forces smaller establishments to reduce their profit margins or risk losing customers. Additionally, big companies typically have larger marketing budgets, making it difficult for small businesses to maintain visibility in their communities.

(3) However, the relationship between big and small businesses is not entirely negative. Many small enterprises have found success by specializing in areas where large corporations cannot compete effectively. By offering personalized customer service, unique products, or specialized knowledge of local preferences, small businesses can create loyal customer bases. Some small businesses even benefit from the increased foot traffic that big companies bring to commercial areas.

(4) Technology has both complicated and improved this relationship. Online marketplaces dominated by large corporations have created new challenges for small retailers. Yet, these same digital platforms sometimes provide opportunities for small businesses to reach customers beyond their local areas. Social media has also become an essential tool, allowing small businesses to build communities and connect with customers in ways that larger companies often struggle to achieve.

(5) Looking forward, the most successful small businesses will likely be those that can adapt to the changing marketplace while maintaining their unique identities. Many communities have begun to recognize the cultural and economic value of local businesses, leading to

movements and small business support programs. For their part, some forward-thinking large corporations have started partnering with small businesses, recognizing that a diverse business ecosystem ultimately benefits everyone involved.

questions.question: Which form correctly completes the sentence? 'If I _____ more time, I would have finished the project yesterday.'
